Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company settled securities law violations for failing to sufficiently disclose the potential negative impact of a cap it placed on a complex investment product that investors were planning to use for retirement.

Private Litigation Case Title: Gordan et al v. Mass Mutual Life Insurance Co. et al
Golden Star, Inc. v. Mass Mutual Life Insurance Co.

Description: Great American Life agreed to pay $400,000 to settle multistate litigation regarding its use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.
Info Source: Four Additional Insurers Agree to Change Their Use of Death Master File, States News Service, August 4, 2016 (via Nexis).

Description: The Minnesota Attorney General reached a settle with Great American Life Insurance and its affiliate Annuity Investor's Life Insurance Company regarding the sale of deferred anuities to senior citizens under which customers would be able to make refund claims involving approximately 2,000 policies with an estimated value of $50 million.
Info Source: Minnesota Attorney General Achieves Settlement with Great American over Annuities Sales, Targeted News Service, December 22, 2009 (via Nexis).

Company: Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, Inc.

Description: violations of New York Insurance regulations in deferred to immediate annuity replacement transactions
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
Pennsylvania Department of Banking and Securities

Description: misappropriation of funds by a sales representative
Agency: Rhode Island Department of Business Regulation

Description: NASD settled cases against four firms involving mutual fund sales violations.
Info Source: NASD Settles Cases Against MML Investors Services, NYLIFE Securities, Securities America and Northwestern Mutual Investment Services for Fines Totaling over $1.2 Million for Failures Relating to Mutual Fund Sales, States News Service, June 28, 2007 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

NAICS Translation: 561790: Other Services to Buildings and Dwellings
